title: BLAST Magazine Serif Text face resembles De Vinne
content:
Found this sample in [Blast Magazine](http://web.archive.org/web/20150415033627/http:/dl.lib.brown.edu/mjp/render.php?id=1158591480633184&view=mjp_object) by Wyndham Lewis.

Later digital versions that are similar but not quite (see the large ear in /g/ for example) include [Hawthorne](http://web.archive.org/web/20150415033627/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/hawthorn-lt/) and [Romana](http://web.archive.org/web/20150415033627/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/bitstream/romana/).

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [Screen Shot 2013-09-12 at 5.57.12 PM.png](http://web.archive.org/web/20150415033627/http:/typophile.com/files/Screen%20Shot%202013-09-12%20at%205.57.12%20PM.png) | 66.29 KB |
| [Screen Shot 2013-09-12 at 5.57.01 PM.png](http://web.archive.org/web/20150415033627/http:/typophile.com/files/Screen%20Shot%202013-09-12%20at%205.57.01%20PM.png) | 49.38 KB |
author: hashiama

comments.content:
---start quote---  
Blast 1 was edited and largely written by Wyndham Lewis ... Inside, Lewis used a range of bold typographic innovations and tricks to engage the reader....  
---end quote---  
source:  
 [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blast\_%28magazine%29](http://web.archive.org/web/20150415033627/http:/en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blast_%28magazine%29 "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blast\_%28magazine%29")  
Perhaps Lewis included tinkering with the DeVinne font, which was widely used in 1914, as part of his typographic innovations.  
Don

I dont think he tinkered with DeVinne, that quote refers probably to sans serif pages such as these ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150415033627im_/http:/upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/6/6c/BlastFirst.jpg)
